scenarios.title: Hurricane Relief
scenarios.description: Lead an emergency response team in a city devastated by a hurricane. Your choices will determine the direction and impact of your relief efforts.

prompts.text: A flooded neighborhood is in desperate need of help. How will you approach the rescue?
A child is trapped inside a partially collapsed home. What do you do?
Residents are stranded on rooftops. How will you get them down safely?
The storm knocked out communications. How do you reestablish contact with other rescue teams?
An injured survivor begs you to help, but danger is still present. Whatâ€™s your move?
Weather conditions are worsening. How do you ensure your team's safety while continuing relief efforts?
Supplies are running low. How do you ration resources without causing panic?
The floodwater may be contaminated. How do you keep your team and survivors safe from disease?
Some buildings are unstable but house survivors. How do you handle the rescue?
Your team is exhausted after hours of work. How do you balance rest with ongoing emergencies?
Local volunteers want to help but lack training. How do you involve them?
Displaced families need shelter. How do you coordinate housing with locals?
Food distribution is chaotic. How do you organize it fairly?
Children are frightened and panicking. How do you comfort them and keep them safe?
Community leaders want to take charge. How do you collaborate without losing control?

answers.text: Lead the rescue personally, risking dangerous conditions.
Form a team of volunteer heroes and push into the hardest-hit area.
Climb onto rooftops using improvised ladders to save stranded residents.
Swim through floodwaters to reach survivors despite the hazards.
Carry the injured out on your back even under threat of collapse.
Borrow a local boat and lead a daring water rescue mission.
Rush into the collapsed home with minimal equipment to save the child immediately.
Signal for air support by climbing a radio tower despite risks.
Push ahead with no rest until every last survivor is accounted for.
Dive underwater to rescue someone trapped beneath debris.
Wait for first responders with proper gear before entering.
Set up checkpoints to monitor team members and ensure no one is exposed to unnecessary risk.
Distribute supplies slowly, keeping reserves hidden for emergencies.
Set up a rationing schedule and document all distributions transparently.
Avoid unstable structures until engineers can confirm safety.
Provide clean bottled water only, warning survivors against floodwater.
Assign rest shifts for rescuers to avoid burnout.
Use drones to scout dangerous areas before sending in people.
Evacuate slowly and methodically, prioritizing the safest routes.
Request reinforcements from nearby towns before continuing.
Organize a community meeting and assign roles.
Provide basic training sessions for volunteers before deploying them.
Work with local schools and churches to turn them into temporary shelters.
Encourage families with safe housing to temporarily host displaced neighbors.
Assign volunteers to food distribution lines to maintain order.
Create activity groups for children to calm them and keep them occupied.
Translate critical instructions into multiple languages for inclusivity.
Set up a neighborhood watch-style team to ensure safety in shelters.
Let community leaders run logistics while you focus on rescue efforts.
Hold nightly briefings to keep everyone informed and motivated.
